alert.note: Alert for Polk (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 17 at 1:00AM CDT until April 21 at 5:30PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Major severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Minnesota... Red Lake River at Crookston affecting Polk County. .An ice jam is likely affecting the river levels on Red Lake River at Crookston MN. An additional increase into major flood stage is possible as ice moves through the area. Fluctuations of several feet are possible. Uncertainty exists of rate of rise and fall as ice moves through, in addition to river levels into mid to late this week due to forecast chance for precipitation and cooler than average temperatures. Historic ice jam crests are as follows.. 24 feet in 2010. 20.8 feet in 2011. 22.4 feet in 2013. 21.3 feet in 2014. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR AN ICE JAM NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red Lake River at Crookston. * WHEN...Until Friday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD STAGE. EOC activated if advised by EOC Committee. At 23.0 feet, MAJOR FLOOD STAGE. Ward Command Posts activated if advised by EOC Committee. Levee patrols begin. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:25 AM CDT Monday the stage was 21.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:25 AM CDT Monday was 21.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is forecast to rise to a crest of near 23.0 feet this morning. There is uncertainty in exact crest due to ice jam. It will then fall below flood stage late Thursday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
